reasoning: This targets a central load-bearing move in the paper: whether a Jones-style rapid process reconfiguration can quickly raise effective substitutability (ρ) toward 0 despite fixed compute, which would materially change SIE plausibility and thus strategic posture (high cruciality). It is tightly anchored to the paper’s specific analogy/assumption about short-run vs long-run bottlenecks and the effective ρ framing (high paper-specificity). It’s partially answerable via empirical studies of agentic R&D orgs (e.g., throughput vs agent-count under fixed compute, measurement of coordination/eval bottlenecks, interventions like automated experiment pipelines), but the extreme scaling regime (100–10,000×) and “within weeks” claim make clean identification difficult (moderate tractability). The core question is understandable, but terms like “reconfigure” and “marginal productivity stops collapsing” need more operational definition/metrics (good but not perfect clarity). The branch-point framing and implied update to whether compute bottlenecks bind early vs late gives a clear decision-relevant hook. Some bullet-point scaffolding is helpful, but a bit is non-essential context (low-to-moderate dead weight).
title: Organizational reconfiguration speed vs. labor productivity collapse
